title: Before 20 July 2018, will Audi sell or lease a motor vehicle with Traffic Jam Pilot?
preds: Just going to zero due to the time frame.
9 days left, no announcement so far
TJP is explicitly excluded from the US A8 that launched already this ear, and will not come to the EU models "until some time in 2019"
Ignore this service message: Clearing out May 24 bets. No change.
Traffic Jam Pilot is still hampered by inconsistent regulatory laws, it seems.
Back to 0 in light of the March clarification and legislative timeline of October as stated in article [1] below.
Regulations in different Countries are hard to please with these new technology.

The technology is simply not "there" at this moment. A recent article on a technology site made this observation about self-driving vehicles in general: "The word “autonomous” is often used to describe assist systems that still require an alert human driver, leading to the potential for major confusion." Basically the general population still doesn't understand that at this point, you can not safely take the human driver out of the equation. Not to mention all of the unanswered legal and insurance related aspects of autonomous driving which have to be solved.  https://www.digitaltrends.com/cars/2019-audi-a8-traffic-jam-pilot-not-coming-to-us/ If you are behind the wheel of one of these vehicles, and a software glitch causes you to collide with another motorist before you could manually react, is the manufacturer at least partially at fault?
Not going to be in the A8 (https://www.digitaltrends.com/cars/2019-audi-a8-traffic-jam-pilot-not-coming-to-us/)

One continues to assume that this Q means "offers to the public for sale or lease vehicles with this feature," and not what it literally says, which implies a Yes if they sell one to Consumer Reports for testing.  So staying low, and should probably go lower.  English can be a tricky language.

Found one UK article stating that Traffic Jam Pilot will be activated in Germany, but not seeing anything in German press to confirm this has happened. The articles I found still refer to testing (and to Chinese companies copying the technology).

Not sold in USA until Spring 2019 (and even then unsure if enabled)
https://www.caranddriver.com/news/2019-audi-a8-official-photos-and-info-news
Audi is very stable in their place in the market. Their customers are not very interested in self driving technology. They will be slow to find customers in their current base who will demand it.
Interesting article from the UK about self-driving cars. I'm still not sure if Traffic Jam Pilot is activated in Germany.
The expected release date is late 2018, after July
I would have done 1-2%, but my prediction sat at 8% for a long time, and I now find it even more highly unlikely.
Reducing in light of recent accident plus the Feb 2018 DfT announcement for the UK legislation.
This was a low chance to start but the recent pedestrian death decreases the chances of a release.

Audi is a premiere brand - their reputation is everything. They don’t need to be first (ex. Apple is never first). They need to ensure they don’t risk the brand and be a fast/quality follower. Recent pedestrian death in Arizona will have everyone regrouping/strategizing.
News of pedestrian death by way of automated vehicle will decrease likelihood.
Such a pivotal issue --- caution seems likely.  A disheartening trial run would have a heavy price

Audi will only introduce Traffic Jam Pilot to those markets where it is legal to use to its full potential. Assume the legal issues will be solved in Germany first, thus it would be the likely point of introduction. A lot has to go right with hardware, software, and legalware all synching at the same time. Local dealer must also be able to maintain the system - this would seem to be the final nut to crack and further limiting it to country of origin.

Audi has never been known for having advanced technology in thier cars, however I would still make a 25% prdiction that they will relaesase a car with Traffic Jam Pilot becasue it seems that all major car companies are adapting this technology.

Over the past three years, BMW has taken ConnectedDrive services into over 25 new markets, with availability in a total of 30. Audi is clearly determined to match BMW with a service here in the US. That said, Audi would need to secure DOT approval, set the stage with its distribution network in advance and release a PR and ad/promo effort.
The current state of autonomous vehicles technology seems to have generated a race within Auto manufacturers
I am skeptical that the technology will have been tested enough by then.
Why should Audi not wait for a better opportunity of profiling in this area?
I have  deal with my gut. I feed it well and it never lies to me.
No credible or recent(within 6 months) news releases regarding cities or regions where this would be allowed by governing authorities.
I do not believe it will occur.

The most recent news (late fall of 2017) was that the system worked - with many caveats.   With VW still doing damage control from the emissions scandal - and knowing German philosophies when it comes to doing something - I believe that they are going to continue to test and refine the code beyond the July 20, 2018 deadline.   I think it will finally be announced in mid-fall 2018.
Past performance of AUDI and developments in the area of AI push me to adopt that estimation.
They are already leaking news of it on car blogs.  However, it will not be in the US first.  In Russia, they are already using Semis without drivers.
Too soon for Audi to launch Traffic Jam Pilot.
At this time there is a pilot level3, but not in all countries allowed. Level4 is near.

Audi stands to be eclipsed by Cadillac's Super Cruise. While the Audi system is better, the battle is to be first in the public's mind (refer to Honda v. Toyota hybrid introductions - Honda was first, but Toyota stuck). Audi will push for a lease option.
Audi has the reputation of having introduced higher automotive technology in many of its standard models, A8 being one of them.
Its way too early for a sale

Flagships like the A4 normally receive their new tech. We could see an Q series "e" vehicle that could incorporate lvl 2 autonomy, but I don't believe that July will fall in line with their facelift strategy employed by Audi (they JUST released the 2018 model). My bet, 2020, that falls in line with the facelift.
Technically it may be ready (or nearly so), but huge driver interface issues and regulatory concerns. Doubt it will happen by this July.

Germany seems to be the most likely to be the first to allow the Traffic Jam Pilot but this article is from September 2017 so will have to keep following for more recent developments coming from these talks.
Levels of autonomy can be reduced for initial sells, and increased as software is proven or improved.  Also can be adjusted for regulations.

Just keeping it “real” 5%. Per others, maybe it is baked into some vehicles but reputation is everything. If an Autonomous Audi hits a tree in a forest and no one is there to witness it, they’ll be reading about it in days. The fake unintended acceleration complaints Audi suffered in 1980’s took years to overcome. It has to be (near) perfect and as per California DMV stats on autonomous cars, the car could be functioning perfectly and still get a bad rap due to some slack-jawed yokel texting while driving (in another vehicle).its coming, but Thinking not by July 20.
first forecast must do more research.
A little confusing, as A8 is selling with traffic jam pilot switched off. To be turned on sometime in 2018, theoretically.
If the question is worldwide, I think answer is high.
Audi is lagging compared to other car companies on the level of automation they are putting into their cars

It looks like Germany has now passed laws that will allow Level 3 autonomous vehicles, in anticipation of this vehicle being launched. I haven't seen any evidence of a firm launch date by Audi but the cars have been tested and now that the laws are passed, it seems to be a reasonable possibility that this will happen.

Moving toward consensus as the question doesn't indicate whether sales/leases need to have a Traffic Jam Pilot enabled. I'd still like to see some more convincing global sales launch dates, though. Article [2] indicates launches happening "now" (as of early February) but I'd still like to see some more definitive global sales launch dates (I'll have to comb through comments here).

It seems as though Audi is still in the development stage, so I don't see this being released in July- in part also because it's after the big auto shows.  But, I do think that they will continue with this release at some point over the next 2 years.  This may not be a world-wide release, but targeting specific areas of Europe that deal with highway traffic for which this program would be useful to the user.

Even when the A8 was already presented last year, Audi has not announced any advancement in legal permissions to sell the vehicle with the Autonomous Driving level 3, current legislation only permits level 2.
Audi's been working hard on that.

With Audi having a fully-baked system in the Traffic Jam Pilot, regulations are the remaining roadblock to selling or leasing a vehicle equipped with this system. Laws and regulations have traditionally lagged research and development, and remains murky from the standpoint of traditional automakers. Unless laws are passed which clarifies the various legal conundrums inherent in Level 3 autonomous cars, Audi will err on the side of caution and will only promote this system in a "Preview Mode", and not sell or lease a vehicle with this system.
If introduced it will be with Model Year 19 A8 not expected in market by that date
The car has been tested by auto journals for the 2019 model, which should release in the summer of 2018. No significant hurdles seem to be left.

If they have the tech they may risk it.  Auto pilot is the next huge venture.  Audi may risk it inorder to take the lead on the emerging tech.  The risk is that fatalities will be sensationalized and Audi will take a big hit to the brand.
I can’t see it on the street by this date. Do pre-orders count?
They have this model already and are simply waiting on approval, which will take place within the next 3 months
Legal impediments in most jam-prone jurisdictions will slow implementation.
The technology will not be ready by Jul 2018

Audi has already begun testing this self-driving feature and there is industry pressure to provide self-driving features on automobiles in the US. Articles last year in Tech Crunch, Car Magazine and Car and Driver referenced.

Too many variables in city driving to model and predict in real time.  However, a totally safe system could be made that would not appeal to anybody but city planners and traffic engineers.  In other words, not designed for the individual owner.
The system seems to be pretty much done, but in Germany they will release it only in 2019 for legal reasons. I doubt that they  will provide it at release in the US.
Cadillac already has a similarly-capable system called SuperCruise - it has not proven popular. I predict a similar fate for Audi.
People undestimate time required for things like this
No state will approve use by then. Marketing lull behind Tesla's frontier application in market.
Would require more time to market.
I do not know much but it seems a bit aggressive at this point.  20% is probably too high, but I don't know enough to be certain about "no"
Because I want to do so and German engineering is some of the world's best.

Self driving cars are being developed.  I am assuming that the sales of the car will be in the US.  If it is somewhere in the world, then the probability will be significantly higher.  There is a lot of headwind to bring a self driving car to US markets (insurance, trust, and cost).
Audi would not be expected to risk a public issue which could do damage to the technology and company  reputations.

I imagine something like this would require lots and lot of testing.  Nothing worse than finding gremlins afterwards.  5 months may not be enough time to work through the process to be at a point of selling or leasing.
Had not rolled out in Germany as of 11/17. Autotrader: The updated 2019 Audi A8 will first go on sale in Germany in the fall of 2017 and then make its way to the U.S. by early-to-mid 2018.
Previous consumer reports/reviews put the launch of Traffic Jam Pilot at late 2019.
Number of hurdles makes this unlikely.
Preparations for all the steps are not in place. Also the state/county governments have not finished their assessments in the testing counties.

Vag group has historically rolled out new programs and new Innovations into their Audi vehicles particularly targeting higher-end consumers. Many of which are considering some type of autonomous vehicle such as a Tesla, to keep up with those exact customers I think that there is a chance that they will release this quickly.
I think new technology is happening faster ass the car manufacturers do not want to loose the chance to be the first cat to have the coolest technology.
Rolling this out without extensive public trial is nearly unthinkable

unlikely in the US due to regulations.  it is more likely in Germany, where they seem to be more open to changing laws to adapt to the tech.  also, new models usually debut in 4th qtr.  Audi might make a move to release earlier in order to be the first, but this seems unlikely.

Seems constrained in where it could be driven  "For now, Traffic Jam Pilot only engages if the system can meet a checklist of parameters. It has to be on a limited-access divided highway; it needs to have a vehicle directly in front and a line of slow-moving vehicles in adjacent lanes; and the system needs to be able to make out lane markings and the edge of the roadway (with a barrier or guardrails, for instance." https://blog.caranddriver.com/traffic-jamming-in-the-2019-audi-a8-we-let-automated-driving-tech-take-the-wheel/

I continue to rank low (0%). If they sell or lease said vehicle they can’t geofence it (restrict it geographically). That means adverse weather and traffic conditions. Audi is a top tier marque and can’t risk their reputation - that rep is what gets people to pony up the Benjamins. I realize the function is restricted to specific criteria (basically traffic jams). Challenged to believe something will be out there in 5 months. As
Mentioned previously, more likely baked into flagship A8 to combat MB S class - so later in year.
Never launch a new vehicle in the middle of July! Specially in the northern hemisphere. Second never launch a vehicle in the middle of the winter in the southern hemisphere!
The governements of the world have no law of regulations.
Leaving aside that Traffic Jam Pilot sounds like a sloppy translation for a Japanese cartoon character, the planets are not yet aligned for this.  Maybe by year-end, though.
I estimate the probability of Audi being technically able to have the system installed in showroom cars within a 2-3 month time frame to be 0.6.
Due to the affirmative rating from the Economist, coupled with the fact that more manufacturers in the segment are offering autonomous features, this seems most probable.

Barriers to production and programming as well as local regulations and law would make production of this exciting, but not necessarily a priority. They've been testing it for awhile, but it is unlikely that this company will get through the red tape in five months.

I don't think Audi will get government permission this early. In my view, their best shot is getting the permission in Germany but I don't think the new German government will be in a rush to grant the permission. Although it looks like the designated minister is generally in favor of granting it and helping the german automobile industry on this front.
Limited time for testing and to gain appropriate government and liability releases compared to the brand value of early release.

Computer vision is at a tipping point where we are beginning to know what we don't know, but it is not refined enough yet for open source or non-customized solutions. For this reason, level 3 autonomy is difficult and has not been fully attained by any auto company. Since the release vehicles are not currently equipped with Traffic Jam Pilot and there is questionable regulatory oversight, Audi will not take the liability of releasing a level 3 vehicle. Instead, they will release level 2 vehicles with level 3 capabilities to continue testing.
Computer and algorithms are not anywhere close yet.

There was a flurry of news in September and October 2017 and no news since then. Self-driving cars appear to be more difficult than is perceived, and the public will not be satisfied with a car that’s top autonomous speed is 35 mph. So even if they achieve it, it’s unlikely to be released for sale or lease.

Given the legal framework in Europe and the US as well as the pace of change for it (and the insurance / liability ramifications) the A8 is not very likely to go commercial before the end of 2018 the earliest.
Perhaps as a Beta test; meaning Audi might "sell" cars with this technology to selected client(s) as a trial if legal (Germany, perhaps).

Auto manufacturers are constantly working to offer new, and relevant products and features in their vehicles.  Time is money, and traffic can impede a driver and their ability to arrive on time for work, meetings, etc.  Even if Audi doesn't offer this by the deadline, it still seems like something they would offer in the very near future.

It seems like the software is there, just about. They just need some easy place to prove it.  I'm sure they can find an "owner" that will take such a vehicle under certain restrictions while they build confidence i.e. a trial that morphs into normal usage. Since we are heading towards car companies leasing and maintaining their fleets of electric autonomous city based vehicles rather than selling ego boosters to the general public this may well turn out to be a loan of several vehicles to a small, easily navigable test town.
Too soon. Need more regulations first.

This is based on a single date and that date is subject to political climate.  Some autonomous vehicles are currently on the roads.  A mishap anywhere in the world would affect the release date.   Audi will release the car by July 20th if mishaps or government don't cause a delay.
July 18 seems too soon to resolve regulatory issues, but a defeatured version of TJP could be introduced in '19 models.
Reduced probability because of news articles saying they won't be able to deliver with this model

Audi wants to stay in the competition with Tesla, which already has a restricted Level 3 system. As far as I can tell, Audi's technology is as advanced as Tesla's. Audi needs to introduce it soon to stay ahead of the pack/

My answer would be 0% if it was about making that date and being released to the general public.  But the question does not specify which vehicle or country it could take place in.  So for those reasons I am giving it  40% chance.  I strongly believe it will happen by 2019 and that laws will be crafted to allow Level 3 autonomy.  The future will happen whether we like it or not.  This being a palatable stepping stone for the full automation to come.

According to CNET, Audi has said that Traffic Jam Pilot will not be available at the time of the new A8 (the first model to have the feature) release in Fall 2018, but that it would be rolled out sometime thereafter, likely in 2019.
As long Level 3 regulations are not implemented, they want build cars with the pilot. Although the system is ready to use.
This needs to get through US legal traffic jams first. Wait until the A8 in 2019.

There don't seem to be any plans to include a fully functional Traffic Jam Pilot in any cars until the 2019 A8 model is released, presumably in late 2018. Even then, Audi has to hope that some agreement can be reached on legislation to accommodate the feature.
Audi has a number of new, revamped models being released prior to July 2018.

Not before the 3rd or 4th quarter, I shouldn't think.  On the other hand, the question doesn't require it to be a production model available to everyone, based on the singular noun.  Sloppy wording is what we have all come to expect around here, and one is never sure what if anything language means any more, but it looks to me as if they lease a demo version of a motor scooter or a golf cart to some individual in St. Louis, this Q will be a Yes.
Because  it is something people will adopt readily and its introduction poses little public danger
The Audi's definitely won't reach the US until 2019. They might be in Europe sooner if Germany gets its legislation in order, but likely July is to soon
Too complex to roll out yet

2017 Audi A8 revealed as brand's most high-tech model yet
Audi's new flagship shows off the firm's new look and is crammed with sophisticated technology; on sale in October
https://www.autocar.co.uk/car-news/new-cars/2017-audi-a8-revealed-brands-most-high-tech-model-yet

I think Audi has a significant stake in securing a first-mover position in L3 autonomy among luxury manufacturers. The biggest potential snag would be a lack of complete legal specifications, which would force Audi to either wait until the laws are in place so they can fit their sensors to the law, or make a "best guess" and potentially waste money/effort on a system that doesn't meet the legal standard.
Audi is a good and innovative company
Technic available, law is the problem. Time frame until 20.July 2018 is tight.

I’m lowering based on fact Audi A8 is most likely platform to receive first (flagship). Tough to say when it will be released to USA (mid year). When released, likely L2 only enabled - but L3 may be there and only require an update to enable. Maybe in Deutschland earlier?

I wish the question was a little more precise. IE, being sold in America Vs Germany. Also if the sale is limited to consumer sales. I would most likely rank the question lower of both answer were affirmative.
This seems unlikely in the time frame. According to what I've read (see link) cars with this capability will not be available until late 2018.
With the new government still pending it is not likely that the regulations will be changed before 20th July 2018 in order to remove the legal obstacles.

Tha Audi A8 D5 which is supposed to come with the traffic jam pilot is already released in germany. For legal reasons, it is not expected to have th seemingly fully developed traffic jam pilot in germany up until late 2018, most likely 2019. The same car will be released in the US in 2019. 
So the only chances of it happening are some kind of legal miracle in germany, audi releasing on another market earlier, or another car by audi with the system being released in the Us earlier. The Uk release seems to be planned for earlier this year, so that or audi testing the feature on another european market seem to be the most likely scenarios. Wheter this couls happen also depends on how much testing audi has done on foreign roads already.

only goes to 60km/h so perfect for traffic jams. Unaware of any announcements from Audi re. Release date but seems to be baked in at design level of new A8. So they could do it quickly and maybe quietly (over deliver - how Teutonic). Guessing unlikely in USA until legal stuff worked out - but maybe in Germany? Until I know more 35%.
It seems the fall would be the earliest.
